dataModel.title: Prototype Veg Plots Database Component Description: plot
dataModel.author: J. Harris

entity.entitySummary: This table stores general information about the a given plot loaction

attribute.attNotes: G
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value that is unique to each plot

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key to the project table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a given project.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stand table.
attribute.attDefinition: The attribute used to identify which stand from which the plot was sampled.

attribute.attNotes: In case of plot records taken from the literature, this field will link the plot record with a citation in a child entity.
attribute.attDefinition: Author's Plot number/code - original plot number.

attribute.attNotes: This attribute has a recursive relationship with the plot_id attribute
attribute.attDefinition: Attribute refers to a parent plot - which is the plot_id for which this plot is a sub-plot.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the namedPlace table.
attribute.attDefinition: Attribute to track if the plot was collected with an area corresponding to a 'named place'.

attribute.attNotes: Database will determine this based on the number of fields in which data are entered. If the database determines the plot to be 'ancillary' the person entering the data will be warned.
attribute.attDefinition: Type of plot (vegetation/ancillary).

attribute.attNotes: Each method will have its own metadata record with more descriptive detail about sampling method, especially if it is not a standard method. This will include dimensions, number and arrangement of subplots (quadrats, microplots, etc.) in stand, etc. Each combination of method and cover scale will have its own (external) application to convert cover data to the database standard.
attribute.attDefinition: Sampling method used to describe the plot. This will be a pick list with standard plot description methods, such as Daubenmire, modified Daubenmire, Zurich-Montpellier, North Carolina Vegetation Survey and TNC (I am not sure whether TNC should be listed separately or should be considered a ZM sampling approach using a different cover scale). Other methods can be added to pick list as needed.

attribute.attNotes: A note should be attached to this field describing the cover classes if a non-standard cover scale or a modification of a standard scale is used. Alternatively, a separate field could be used to describe the cover scale, and the system could fill in this information automatically for the scales in the picklist.
attribute.attDefinition: Scale used to estimate species cover. This does not follow necessarily from the sampling method in the previous field. For instance, the ZM method can use the standard Braun-Blanquet scale, the Barkman et al. cover scale, or some other modified BB scale. Similarly, the modified Daubenmire method can use the Franklin et al. or the Pfister-Arnold cover scale. The pick list will include the following categories: several frequently used standard cover scales, and a choice of "absolute cover and "non-standard cover scale.

attribute.attNotes: I suggest we use Lat./Long. rather than the UTM grid reference, because the latter cannot be used in polar regions. Our input tools will need converters between UTM and Lat/Long.
attribute.attDefinition: Original latitude of the plot origin.

attribute.attNotes: See notes above
attribute.attDefinition: Original longitude of the plot origin.

attribute.attNotes: This will be used to calculate the Lat/Long points stored within the attribute dsgpolyo
attribute.attDefinition: Shape of the plot area.

attribute.attNotes: Plot size is an aggregate of noncontiguous plots, we need to flag this in someway or we will get inflated estimates of species density.
attribute.attDefinition: Area over which all species were identified and their cover was estimated in meters-squared.

attribute.attNotes: Initially we were thinking of measuring this value in meters and using the following criteria: 1 = GPS within 10-20 m 2 = GPS within 25 50 m 3 = Determined by map; within 200 m 4 = Weak guess from map; within 1 km 5 = General locality; within 10 km 6 = Region only; within 100 km 7=user entered numeric value
attribute.attDefinition: The accuracy of the plotSize in percentage of the plotSize.

attribute.attNotes: n/a
attribute.attDefinition: The altitude of the plot origin in meters.

attribute.attNotes: n/a
attribute.attDefinition: The accuracy of the altValue in percentage of the altValue.

attribute.attNotes: User to enter general values like: NE which would be translated via the interface to 045 degrees, or allow user to enter exact coordinates.
attribute.attDefinition: Azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees).

attribute.attNotes: Provide user with categories to choose from such as: Flat; slope less than 1% (less than 0deg 34') Gentle; slope 1-10% (0deg 34'-5deg 43') Moderately sloping; slope 10-25% (5deg 43'-13deg 59') Steep; slope 25-50% (13deg 59'-26deg 34') Very steep; slope 50-100% (26deg 34'-45deg 0') Cliff; slope greater than 100% (greater than 45 deg)
attribute.attDefinition: Inclination of slope in degrees.

attribute.attNotes: Categories may include: Summit, shoulder, upper slope, middle slope, lower slope, toeslope, no slope.
attribute.attDefinition: Position of the plot on slope.

attribute.attNotes: Non-Tidal 1) Permanently flooded 2) Intermittently exposed 3) Semi-permanently flooded 4) Seasonally flooded 5) Saturated 6) Temporarily flooded 7) Intermittently flooded 8) Artificially flooded 9) Unknown Tidal 1) Subtidal 2) Irregularly exposed 1) Regularly exposed 2) Irregularly flooded 3) Unknown
attribute.attDefinition: FGDC hydrologic regime (follows Cowardin et al. 1979.)

attribute.attNotes: e.g., outwash sand, glacial till, etc.
attribute.attDefinition: Surface geology type.

attribute.attNotes: The number of user defined fields must be determined. As of the Septemeber 2000 working group meeting at NCEAS the actual number has yet to be defined.
